column3: of the airport. [SEP] Some stretches of sand are so magnificent and the water so warm, it’s hard to believe that they were ignored for so long by the Balinese people, who have traditionally turned away from the sea. [SEP] Now visitors come in the millions from all over the world with little in mind but sun, sand, warm seas, and watersports. [SEP] Sanur

[SEP] For a list of venues ask Tourinform or see the Sports and Leisure section in the Budapest Sun. [SEP] Golf. [SEP] This is a newcomer to Hungary, and you will have to

[SEP] In the winter, first-class cross-country skiing is available in Yosemite Valley and its surrounding wild country. [SEP] There are also downhill skiing areas at Badger Pass near Yosemite and in Squaw Valley near Lake Tahoe. [SEP] Other popular ski resorts are the Mammoth Lakes in the Eastern Sierra and Big Bear Lake, a few hours
column3: from L.A. For a full list of skiing resorts, ask at a Visitor Information Center (see page 123) for the Winter Sports Guide.

column1: Tiburon is the quieter of the two, while Sausalito is more of a tourist trap, but both have a colorful Mediterranean atmosphere, with art galleries, yacht harbors, craft shops, and pleasant bistros and cafés out on the boardwalk overlooking the bay. [SEP] Farther inland is the woodsy residential paradise of Mill Valley, and behind it rises the 2,604-ft (794-m) summit of Mount Tamalpais. [SEP] The mountain bike was invented here in the 1970s, and there are plenty of hiking and biking trails, but if you’re feeling lazy you can
column3: along the Panoramic Highway to within a few hundred yards of the summit. [SEP] The view from the top is memorable — across the bay to the city and then beyond to Mount Diablo, and on a clear day you might even catch a glimpse of the beautiful Sierra Nevada mountains. [SEP] Highway 1 twists through the hills to the coast, past the Muir Woods National Monument, named after John Muir, the Scots-born environmentalist, who founded California’s conservation movement at the turn of the 19th century. [SEP] The park protects several groves of magnificent coastal redwoods, some of which are 250 ft (76 m) tall and over 1,000 years old. [SEP] Hiking trails wind among the giant trees.

column1: Berkeley Take the BART subway from Market Street or
column3: across the Bay Bridge to make a pilgrimage to the University of California campus at Berkeley (pronounced BIRK-lee), the scene of 1960s student radicalism. [SEP] Opened in 1873, Berkeley is the oldest of the University of California’s nine campuses. [SEP] Tours of the museums, library, gardens, and other sights are organized from the Student Union at the end of Telegraph Avenue (Monday–Saturday at 10am). [SEP] The free and easy access to the university’s facilities will give you an insight into Berkeley’s open personality. [SEP] The nearby streets are lined with lively cafés and interesting bookshops. [SEP] If you’re driving, head over to Fourth Street for good food and prodigious shopping and people-watching. [SEP] Wine Country

column1: The scenic valleys of Napa and Sonoma have been producing wine on a commercial basis since the middle of the 19th century, and today California wines are considered to be among the finest in the world. [SEP] There are more than 250 vineyards — or wineries as they are called — and most of them offer guided tours and tastings. [SEP] Some of the more interesting wineries to visit are Mondavi, Beringer, Sterling, and Beaulieu in Napa, and Matanzas Creek and Benzinger in Sonoma. [SEP] You can
column3: to the vineyards from San Francisco via Interstate 80, across the Bay Bridge, but bus tours are also available through the major providers. [SEP] You can also arrange a custom tour, visiting wineries of your choice, through Wine Country Jeep Tours (Tel. 800/539-5337, toll-free in US). [SEP] The Napa Valley Wine Train is another option for a scenic hands-off chug through the valley, including lunch or dinner, but no winery visits. [SEP] A note of warning: The entire region, and particularly the Napa Valley, is inundated with visitors all year round, especially on weekends. [SEP] You would be well advised to book lodging, dining, and even tours ahead of time.

[SEP] The centerpiece is the stunning 30-ft- (10-m-) deep Kelp Forest Tank, a window on California’s most important marine habitat. [SEP] Kids will love the Sea Otter Pool and the Touch Pools, where they can both handle and learn about sea anemones, crabs, and even bat rays. [SEP] The 17-Mile Drive is a lovely scenic toll road starting at Lighthouse Avenue in Pacific Grove, a pleasant waterside town of Victorian houses and clapboard cottages a few miles beyond Monterey. [SEP] Meet the trolley on the corner of Rodeo and Dayton Way — it’s the only bargain you’ll find in the neighborhood.

[SEP] You can see Yosemite Creek drop down half a mile from the opposite wall in the spectacular Upper, Middle, and Lower Yosemite Falls, and you’ll get an outstanding view of the majestic Half Dome, a granite monolith sliced in two by the Ice Age glaciers. column1: Nowhere is the clash of traditional values and modern industry more acute than it is in the western Subarctic. [SEP] Here, some 11,000 native peoples from 20 tribes in the Northwest Territories sharing the Athapaskan language have joined as the Dene Nation. [SEP] Together with the Métis Association (descendants of intermarried French fur traders and Plains Indians), they are involved in a tussle with private oil and natural gas companies to protect land rights and traditional culture. [SEP] Proponents of an Arctic gas pipeline passing through Indian lands in the Mackenzie Valley to northern Alberta argued that the Dene need revenues from the pipeline to escape poverty, and that in any case they no longer have an autonomous culture. column3: cars, wear Western clothes, speak English, and play country-and-western music. [SEP] But Dene leaders, fearful of the project’s environmental impact, insisted their bush-related culture of hunting and fishing could and should be protected (through more self-government) before the pipeline was laid. [SEP] Ottawa compromised with a shorter pipeline, one just for oil. [SEP] In fact, quite apart from the more tangible facets of Indian life that the Dene Nation is trying to preserve — language, customs, hunting and fishing grounds —the traditional values are what remain vitally important. [SEP] The Québécois began to settle here in any great numbers only in the second half of the 19th century, when an enterprising curate, Antoine Labelle of St-Jérôme, promoted it as an alternative for peasants who were otherwise immigrating to New England. [SEP] This southeastern edge of the great Canadian Shield proved poor farm country and difficult to exploit for logging, but it really came into its own in the 20th century with the development of tourism. [SEP] In addition to local Montréalers, it attracts steady traffic from New England. [SEP] The heart of the resort area is within an easy 90-minute to 2-hour
column3: from the city for a weekend or longer stay. [SEP] Motorway 15 northwest from Montréal, then Highway 117 take you into forested foothills immediately beyond the metropolis. [SEP] Just 70 km (42 miles) from the city, St-Sauveur-des-Monts makes a charming spot to stop for lunch on one of the roadside flowered terraces. [SEP] In winter, the resort is popular for its floodlit nightskiing. [SEP] Ste-Adèle on the shores of Lac Rond is a favorite with painters and their groupies. [SEP] The town’s Village de Séraphin recaptures the atmosphere of life in the Laurentians in the 1880s.

column3: up the Côte de la Citadelle hill road and through a tunnel for a guided tour around a powerful bastion of fears long gone. [SEP] The French built the starshaped Citadel in 1750 to resist the British. [SEP] The British enlarged it in 1820 to defend Québec City against the Americans, but their cannons never fired a shot in anger. [SEP] The garrison was British-manned for only 20 years before being handed over to Canadian troops. [SEP] Today it is the home of Canada’s crack Royal 22nd Regiment. [SEP] In summertime the garrison comes to life with the Changing of the Guard (10am daily, June 24–first week of Sept.) and Beating the Retreat (6pm Wed–Sat during July and August). [SEP] In any case, many a gourmet or glutton feels that a Halifax lobster dinner is reason enough to make the trip. [SEP] But weight watchers can enjoy Nova Scotia, too. [SEP] There’s the sparkling Atlantic coastline, with its delightful little fishing ports. [SEP] Or rolling green hills across the interior to the orchards and dairy farms of Annapolis Valley. [SEP] This western side of the peninsula is rich in the poignant history of French Acadia. [SEP] You can have a coal miner’s meal at the colliery canteen. [SEP] The great French fortress town of Louisbourg is presented as a splendid national historic park, one of the most elaborate in Canada’s ambitious reconstruction program. [SEP] The forest, a mixture of conifers and hardwoods, shelters white-tailed deer, black bear, moose, beaver, red fox, lynx, mink, and snowshoe hare. [SEP] Bird-watchers can spot, among many species, red-tailed hawk and the occasional bald eagle. [SEP] Fishermen should get their license at the park entrance to angle for trout or salmon (no motorboats allowed). [SEP] Following a common seaport custom, the white clapboard village church, with its nave shaped like an upturned ship, was designed and built by local shipwrights. [SEP] Take a bracing hike along the grassy cliff top west of town, but beware of the winds. [SEP] Southwest of the park, Chéticamp is an old stronghold of Acadian culture, with a museum exhibiting craftware as it was crocheted, spun, hooked, or woven in bygone centuries. [SEP] At the museum’s little restaurant you can sample a traditional meal of clam chowder, meat pâté, and molasses cakes. column1: Stanley Park Covering a magnificent peninsula proudly dominating English Bay, this is undoubtedly one of North America’s finest city parks. [SEP] Its forest of majestic Douglas firs, cedars, and Sitka spruce remind us it was once a government reserve providing mast and spar timbers for the Royal Navy. [SEP] At the turn of the century, the town leased it as a park, named after Lord Stanley, Canada’s governor general. [SEP] His bronze statue is close to the southern entrance. [SEP] Turn east off Georgia Street to take the 9-km (51/2-mile)
column3: looping the park. [SEP] More bracing is the Sea Wall Promenade, where you can walk, jog, or ride a bicycle (available for rent at the park entrance). [SEP] Passing the immaculate green playing field of Brockton Oval, you may spot a cricket game, reminding you this is British Columbia. [SEP] A splendid group of Haida and Kwakiutl totem poles nearby illustrate the province’s other important cultural influence. [SEP] On your way to Brockton Point, listen for the 9 o’clock gun, a cannon that fires at 9pm, originally to warn fishermen of the fishing curfew. [SEP] Turning west, you’ll pass on the seaward side a bronze statue oddly named Girl in a Wet Suit, a version of Copenhagen’s mermaid designed not to shock. [SEP] Stop off at Prospect Point for a good view of oil tankers and grain cargo ships

[SEP] At Craigellachie, right beside the road, about 25 km (15 miles) east of Shuswap Lake, a granite monolith marks the spot where the eastern and western sections linked up to form Canada’s first transcontinental railway. [SEP] At 9:22am on November 7, 1885, surrounded by top-hatted dignitaries and grimy overalled laborers, C.P.R. boss Donald Smith tucked in his flowing white beard and hammered home the famous Last Spike — after misjudging his first swing and bending a first spike over double. [SEP] Leave the Trans-Canada 11/2 km (1 mile) east of Revelstoke town to
column3: the winding Summit Road up Mount Revelstoke, 2,120 m (6,370 ft), the only mountain in Canada that you can “climb” by car. [SEP] This is the cozy way to watch the park’s landscape change from dense lowland forest, through alpine meadows dotted with wild flowers, to the bleak tundra of the high country. [SEP] From the top you look out over the Columbia and Illecillewaet river valleys and back to the Monashee Mountains. [SEP] There are no campgrounds inside the park, but if you’re planning to tent overnight along the 65 km (39 miles) of clearly marked hiking-trails, check in with the park administration office in downtown Revelstoke (P.O. column1: Icefields Parkway This 233-km (140-mile)
column3: on Highway 93, up the spine of the mountain range from Lake Louise to Jasper, gives a rich sense of the Rockies’ varied beauties —  glaciers, waterfalls, lakes, and canyons. [SEP] Take a full day so that you have time to explore some of the sights on foot. [SEP] Stop first at the Crowfoot Glacier, where you can see the foot’s two remaining “toes,” the third having broken away. [SEP] The mass of ice facing you is 55 m (165 ft) thick. [SEP] At Bow Summit, leave the Parkway at the signpost to the viewpoint overlooking the lovely Peyto Lake, a deep turquoise at the height of summer. [SEP] At the Parkway’s Kilometer 200 mark, take Highway 93A to Athabasca Falls. [SEP] A comfortable boardwalk leads you on an informative nature walk right up to where the mighty river plunges over the narrow gorge. [SEP] The old fur trading post of Jasper is now a refreshingly peaceful resort town with a grand park lodge and fine facilities for rafting, canoeing, camping and other mountain sports. [SEP] Take the Jasper Tramway ride up Whistlers Mountain for a view of the Rockies’ highest peak, Mount Robson. [SEP] One of the most attractive excursions is the

column1: Drumheller The area around this old coalmining town is famous for the prehistoric fossils and remarkably complete remains of dinosaurs whose stamping grounds were the Badlands of the Red Deer River Valley. [SEP] The 130-km (78-mile)
column3: northeast of Calgary on Highway 9 takes you through wheat-growing country where you may see the farming communities of Hutterites, an austere religious sect originally from Slovakia, often persecuted for their pacifism. [SEP] The women wear traditional dirndl costumes with headscarf and apron, while their husbands, dressed all in black with broad-rimmed hats, cultivate the heavy beards of Old Testament prophets. [SEP] Drumheller’s Dinosaur Trail places fossils and life-size models of the beasts in their original habitat — though you have to imagine a luxuriant humid jungle in place of the present-day arid desert. column1: Edmonton You can see the source of the provincial capital’s wealth as you
column3: in from the airport. [SEP] On the southern outskirts of town on Highway 2 are the derricks and “grasshopper” pumps that have characterized Edmonton since the oil strike at the great well of Leduc Number 1 in 1947. [SEP] But the town has created another treasure trove in the astounding West Edmonton Mall (Stony Plain Road, Highway 16), a shopping center to end all shopping centers, complete with a waterpark and attracting as many as 140,000 customers on a busy day, 40 per cent of them from the United States. [SEP] If you want a view of the whole city and the North Saskatchewan River on your way home, stop off at Vista 33, the observation level of the telephone building.

column1: The old French-speaking community of St-Boniface, now a Winnipeg suburb, is on the east side of the Red River. [SEP] Its Avenue Taché boasts the city’s oldest building, the 1846 convent of the Grey Nuns. [SEP] It’s now the parish museum, devoted in part to the life of Louis Riel. [SEP] Next door, you’ll find his simple grave in the cemetery of St-Boniface basilica, rebuilt behind its white stone façade after a recent fire. [SEP] Children enjoy the 2-hour ride in the four wooden coaches and caboose of the Prairie Dog Central steam train, from St. James Station to and from Grosse Isle, 25 km (15 miles) northwest of town. [SEP] Where else can you look around a banana plantation and then take a short
column3: half-way up a mountain for a snowball fight? [SEP] Tenerife has been welcoming visitors from cold northern climes since the 19th century. [SEP] However, the focus has changed from the cloudy, green north coast where Puerto de la Cruz was once the favorite resort (it is still enormously popular), to the hot, dry, arid south.

[SEP] Unmissable, also, is the large, uninhabited rock out in the bay, and it has managed to gain for itself a place in the spiritual life of Garachico. [SEP] Without a patron saint of its own, the town has elevated the rock to be its saint! [SEP] Other than a few farms, there is little development until you reach Playa Morena, with its bar and souvenir stand. column3: vehicle), you will eventually reach the northern lighthouse at Punta Molas, having passed the Mayan ruins of El Castillo Real along the way. [SEP] Take the sensible precautions if you make this trip — drinking water, sun protection, insect repellent, and an extra layer of clothing are all advisable. [SEP] The road leading back to San Miguel, called the Carretera Transversal, hosts a few souvenir stands where prices may be a little lower than in town — if you’re prepared to barter. [SEP] Six km (4 miles) from Playa Morena is the entrance to the San Gervasio Archaeological Park. [SEP] The remains of San Gervasio are located several kilometers from the site entrance, and though not on the scale of the major Mayan settlements of the mainland, the beautiful tropical park environment makes the ru

column1: The other big temple in town, Shanhua Monastery, faces the old city wall, which is undergoing renovation. [SEP] The monastery dates from the Tang Dynasty, but it was largely rebuilt after a fire. [SEP] Standing in the grand, red-walled pavilion are 24 celestial guardians, each of distinct mien. [SEP] A circular “moon gate” in the side wall of the monastery leads to the Five Dragon Wall (Wulongbi), transplanted here from a former Confucian temple. [SEP] This ceramic screen resembles the lavish Nine Dragon Wall in the town center, but here the middle dragon, terrifyingly, faces forward. [SEP] A major attraction near Datong is the Temple Suspended Over the Void (Xuankongsi), situated a two-hour
column3: south through a barren sandstone plateau. [SEP] Tours usually stop along the way at one of the area’s cave houses, where residents are happy to show off their hand-dug quarters. [SEP] The sixth-century temple is spectacular, with over 40 halls and pavilions which are joined by ornate catwalks, suspended as if by magic on the face of a sheer limestone cliff. [SEP] Yungang Caves

column1: Leshan From the provincial capital of Chengdu, a three-hour
column3: via a new expressway through populous Sichuan (Szechuan) Province ends at the town of Leshan, the base for visits to a monumental riverside Buddha and to one of four sacred mountains of Chinese Buddhism, Emeishan. [SEP] A 13th-century poet wrote that the most beautiful scenery of China is found in Sichuan, and, indeed, some of the best of that scenery is concentrated in Leshan. [SEP] Here, three rivers converge and flow along the city wall, and far away in the mist rises Mt. Emei. [SEP] Open boats ferry visitors from Leshan to the site of the Great Buddha (Dafo). [SEP] Whether seen from the river or, later, from the hillsides, the world’s largest seated Buddha is an impressive spectacle. [SEP] Carved from the cliffside by a monk starting in the year 713, its height is 71 m (233 ft). [SEP] T

column1: North of Málaga Just an hour’s
column3: north of Málaga lies some magnificent mountain scenery. [SEP] The national park of El Torcal de Antequera is a high limestone plateau that has been eroded by rainwater into a fantasy landscape of fluted pinnacles and towers. [SEP] Hikers can explore the marked trails, which are up to 5 km (3 miles) in length and wind among the rocks, and enjoy panoramic views back to Málaga and the distant blue Mediterranean. [SEP] This is where you will also find a most wonderful small hotel, La Posada del Torcal. [SEP] Near the town of Alora, you will find the breathtaking gorge known as the Garganta del Chorro. [SEP] Three hundred meters (1,000 feet) in depth, this sheer-sided canyon is cut by the Guadalhorce River. [SEP] It is also accessible from Málaga by train; ask for a ticket to El Chorro. [SEP] An

column1: Inland Excursions For a complete contrast to the sun, sea, and sangría atmosphere of the coast, you need only
column3: inland for a few hours to reach the cultural, historical, and architectural attractions of Ronda, Jerez de la Frontera, Sevilla, Córdoba and Granada — the great cities of Andalucía. [SEP] If your time is limited, try one of the day trips offered in all the major resorts or focus your attention on Ronda. [SEP] Most of the other destinations require an overnight stay. [SEP] Ronda

column1: Within its bounds can be found an amazing array of animal, bird, and plant life, but what you see is very much dependent upon the time of year you visit and, even then, can be very hit or miss. [SEP] The only way to really see the park is on a tour organized by Coop. [SEP] Andaluz Marismas del Rocio, whose large-wheel buses depart from the visitors’ center at El Acebuche. [SEP] Be forewarned, though: this is a very bumpy, rough ride, and definitely not advisable for those with artificial hips or physical handicaps. [SEP] Lasting about four hours, it enters the sand dunes at Matalascañas and the first part of the trip is along 35 km (nearly 20 miles) of unspoiled beaches. [SEP] The only human residents here are the fishermen living in what look like very ramshackle huts, albeit with 4-wheel
column3: vehicles and TV antennas on display. [SEP] The vast stretches of salt marshes are fascinating, with many animals living along the edge of the grassland adjoining them. [SEP] The huge sand dunes, perpetually changing, make for a surreal sight. [SEP] Laguna de Medina Across the Guadalquivir and just about 10 km (6 miles) east of Jerez de la Frontera is this small lake, one of the last stops in Europe for birds migrating south from northern and central Europe to Africa at the end of August. [SEP] In periods of drought it is attractive to birds that usually reside at Doñana, and around 50 species have been observed here.

column1: On the road to Knossós, look for the Natural History Museum of Crete — an often overlooked attraction but worthwhile for those who enjoy geology, flora, and fauna. [SEP] Exhibits concentrate on endemic species and the diverse environments that Crete has to offer. [SEP] It also examines man’s effect on the island from his earliest arrival to the present day. [SEP] Other classical sites lay below Iráklion near the south coast. [SEP] Take the road to Agía Vavára, in a vine-filled valley skirting the looming mountains of the Ida range to the west. [SEP] Here you’ll find the Messará Plain, a wide fertile valley surrounded by hills, which has been a center for farming since ancient times. [SEP] For a pretty
column3: along the upper reaches of the valley, take the road to Zarós from Agía Vavára. [SEP] The scenery is magnificent and you can visit Moní Vrontisí, a small monastery in the hills above the town, which was the original home of the Damaskinós icons — now in Agía Ekaterínis in Iráklion. [SEP] This road leads through the villages of Kamáres where there is a large cave, and links up with the Amari Valley to the west (see page 62). [SEP] To reach the ancient sites drop down from Agía Vavára on to the Plain. [SEP] Near the village of Agía Déka — named after ten saints who were martyred here — and widely scattered in farmland, are the remains of Górtis (Gortyn), capital of the island during the Roman era (from 65 b.c.) and also an important city in Minoan times.

column1: Beyond you’ll find the tiny Barrio de Santa Cruz. [SEP] This quarter is all that remains of the Villa Vieja, or old town. [SEP] You can still see fascinating glimpses of traditional narrow streets where houses are decorated with potted plants and wrought-iron grilles. [SEP] From this barrio you’ll be able to see the most prominent sight in Alicante, the historic Castillo de Santa Bárbara, perched 115 metres (350 feet) above the city on Mount Benacantil. [SEP] The site has been fortified since prehistoric times and offers beautiful views of Aitana, San Juan, Santa Pola, and Benidorm and Tabarca islands in the distance. [SEP] To get to the castle,
column3: up the winding road to the summit or use the lift at the far end of Calle Juan Bautista Lafora, close to Postiguet beach. [SEP] Santa Bárbara, built by the Carthaginians in the third century b.c., was so well fortified that for nearly 2,000 years nobody conquered it. [SEP] Only when the French succeeded in blowing up part of the garrison, during the War of the Spanish Succession in 1707, was the castle taken. [SEP] On the opposite side of town in the Barrio San Blas is the smaller Castillo de San Fernando, begun during the War of Independence (1808–1814). [SEP] The castle, set above the trees of the small Parque Municipal, provides a favourite spot for viewing Santa Bárbara and the port in the late afternoon.

column1: Inland from Alicante For a change of scenery,
column3: north of Alicante into the rocky, lunar-like landscape of the Cabeço d’Or mountains. [SEP] This is where you’ll find the Cuevas de Canalobre (Candelabrum Cave), which is reached by following the N-340 from San Juan de Alicante until the turn-off for Busot, where signs mark the way to the cave. [SEP] Floodlights dramatize the eerie ranks of gigantic stalagmites and stalactites, which crowd chambers up to 115 metres (350 feet) high. [SEP] The acoustics are so exceptional that summer concerts are held in the caves. [SEP] Jijona also lies within easy reach of the provincial capital. [SEP] This town, just 27 km (14 miles) from Alicante on the N-340, is renowned for the manufacture of turrón, an exotic sweet of Moorish origin, made from ground almonds, orange-blossom honey, egg white, and sugar.

column1: The North Coast The Costa Blanca’s reputation for magnificent beaches and lively resorts comes from the northern stretch of coast. [SEP] Take the N-332 from Alicante and
column3: through Campello to the fishing port of Villajoyosa. [SEP] This picturesque village, some 30 km (18 miles) from the provincial capital, is more authentically Spanish in character than Benidorm, its cosmopolitan neighbour. [SEP] Wind your way towards the sea through the narrow streets of the old town, and suddenly you’ll see a group of housefronts in sun-bleached blues, pinks, and yellows. [SEP] White-rimmed doors and windows, black wrought-iron grilles, green blinds, and a massive Gothic church give the impression of a sparkling diadem — but then Villajoyosa literally means “Jewelled Town.”

column1: Directly above the old town, the Ermita de San Feliú (Saint Felix’s Hermitage) commands a wide view. [SEP] Although it has been a Christian bastion since the third century, it was a pagan sacrificial site long before that. [SEP] Continue uphill to the fortress, which is, in fact, two castles. [SEP] Ramparts connect the smaller pre-Roman Castillo Menor (Small Castle) with the Roman and post-Roman Castillo Mayor (Main Castle), once notorious for its dungeon. [SEP] Disgraced princes and other noblemen were confined here, their only solace being the ruined 15th-century chapel adjacent. [SEP] Leave Játiva on the C-340 and
column3: up into the highlands where thick-fleeced sheep and isolated farmhouses complete a memorable vista. [SEP] Pass through Albaida, known for its candle-making, and Onteniente, an industrial town, to picturesque Bocairente. [SEP] Visit the village during late summer for the festival of folk dancing, or for February’s Fiesta of Moors and Christians. [SEP] The sombre bull-ring was hacked from solid rock for the Corrida. [SEP] For a town of barely 5,000 inhabitants, Bocairente’s two small museums are impressive: the Museo Histórico (Historical Museum) is noted for a collection of Stone Age pottery, and the Museo Parroquial (Parish Museum) exhibits important paintings by Juan de Juanes, Ribalta, and Sorolla. [SEP] In the hills nearby are Iberian cave tombs, referred to locally as the Covetes de Mor

column1: New Havana The walls surrounding Old Havana were razed during the 19th century to allow the city to expand westward. [SEP] The long, curvaceous, and crumbling Malecón (breakwater), a six-lane highway alongside the city’s north shore, links the districts of Central Havana and Vedado. [SEP] The victim of harmful salt spray, the seafront
column3: is now more a seafront dive. [SEP] At its eastern end, primary-colored buildings — a showcase of tragic splendor — seem to fall apart before your eyes. [SEP] Havana’s youth congregate along the Malecón on fine evenings, flying kites, necking, swimming off the rocks, and setting out to sea in giant inner tubes to fish. [SEP] Although most visitors will want to concentrate on historic and museum-like Old Havana, the newer districts provide a fascinating view of the areas where most people live and work. [SEP] The most interesting districts of New Havana are Central Havana and Vedado. [SEP] The former is a congested, lower-middle-class barrio with few attractions for visitors, although a walk along its dusty streets and crumbling façades can be an eye-opening experience. column1: Playa Santa Lucía An hour-and-a-half
column3: (110 km/68 miles) from Camagüey on the north coast, remote Playa Santa Lucía beckons sun worshippers with resort hotels strung along a particularly fine peninsular strip of sand. [SEP] Each hotel backs directly onto the beach. [SEP] A superb coral reef lies offshore, and diving here is excellent. [SEP] Aside from a couple of roadside bars, however, nightlife is limited to hotel entertainment. [SEP] The only other drawback is the mosquitoes, as voracious as anywhere on the island. [SEP] To counter the isolation of Playa Santa Lucía, the tourist authorities offer a wide range of excursions, including a rodeo at Rancho King, deep-sea fishing, and boat and helicopter trips for days on the beach at such unspoiled cays as Cayo Sabinal and Cayo Saetía. column1: The ruminative buffalo pulls plows and carts, then wallows in the mud of a village pond. [SEP] Chickens run in and out of doorways and often may be seen peering out from roosts on the second floor of houses. [SEP] Under the eaves, bundles of maize hang to dry along with large cucumbers. [SEP] Pumpkin vines climb over rooftops. [SEP] Saturday is a good day to visit Dakshinkali (a 45-minute
column3: from Kathmandu to the southern end of the valley), when thousands of pilgrims bring chickens and goats to sacrifice to Kali. [SEP] Sacrifices also take place on Tuesday. [SEP] The shrine is at the bottom of a shady glen by a brook. [SEP] Carrying their offerings by the feet (incidentally, only male animals may be sacrificed), women form a line on one side and men on the other. [SEP] The altar where the blood will be spilled is out of sight, behind a wall where a loudspeaker screeches hymns to Kali. [SEP] Under a bridge, a cauldron bubbles. [SEP] Decapitated fowl are chucked in to speed the plucking and goats are seared to remove the hair. [SEP] The offal is thrown into the stream.

[SEP] Legend has it that as Vishnu floated partly submerged in the primeval ocean, a lotus grew out of his navel, issuing Brahma, whose sole task was to create the world. [SEP] The king cannot visit this shrine, as to look upon what is considered to be an image of himself, an incarnation of Vishnu, would be a forecast of death. [SEP] On festival days worshippers blanket the statue with flowers. [SEP] Beyond is Shivapuri Watershed and Wildlife Preserve, good place for a day hike. [SEP] If there is any one spot outside the cities that is a must, it is Changu Narayan. [SEP] The oldest temple in the valley and unquestionably one of the most interesting, it sits on an isolated hilltop a few miles north of Bhaktapur and just south of the Sankhu road. [SEP] The
column3: from Bhaktapur cuts across paddies and climbs past thickets of bamboo to the ridge top. [SEP] A misty morning makes the scene even more evocative of the past. [SEP] The temple is in the center of a walled enclosure, with a treasury of small sculptures and shrines dotted about. [SEP] One of several masterpieces dedicated to the cult of Vishnu is a broken eighth-century stone panel, a Licchavi work. [SEP] There is a lovely fifth-century Garuda, and near it, on a memorial pillar, the earliest historical document in Nepal, an inscription of the same period concerning the Licchavi King Manadeva. [SEP] Doors, niches, struts, and cornices are superbly decorated, yet the temple and compound retain a human dimension and are not overwhelming.

column1: From Kathmandu, short trips to the valley rim make it possible for those with limited time to see the high mountains at sunrise or sunset. [SEP] Nagarkot, which stands on the crest of a ridge at 2,195 m (7,200 ft), is about an hour’s
column3: from Bhaktapur and one of the best places in the Kathmandu area for viewing the Himalayas. [SEP] From this aerie on the rim of the Kathmandu Valley, 322 km (200 miles) of the Himalayas stretch out before you in an immense wall of rock and ice. [SEP] Although there are excellent views from the many lodges and hotels here, the view is even better from a nearby observation tower, which can be reached in about an hour’s walk from Nagarkot. [SEP] From this observation tower, it is possible to see as far as Mount Everest. [SEP] Most visitors come for the sunrise or sunset on the mountains, and though the weather is often at its clearest in the early morning, low clouds and fog often obstruct the view. column1: SEP] The land was transformed by hundreds of small wells sunk to extract the precious liquid. [SEP] In 1947 the first offshore rig was opened and the Mississippi valley became a hub of oil and gas production and storage. [SEP] After the Second World War new highways led to broader horizons, and suburbs began to sprawl. [SEP] Following the construction of the impressive causeway across Lake Pontchartrain in 1956, commuters even began to move to the far side of the lake, and NASA assembled thousands of technicians at suburban Michoud to produce its booster rockets. [SEP] Desegregation in schools, which hit many southern cities hard in the 1960s, passed off in New Orleans with a minimum of trouble. [SEP] Whites and blacks had always mixed more freely here than in most places in Dixie, and the
column3: for racial equality reached an historic high in 1977 when Judge Ernest “Dutch” Morial was elected the first African-American mayor. [SEP] Today “Dutch’s” son Marc carries on the family tradition as Mayor. [SEP] But if the city seems to be moving in a positive direction, the state has other problems. [SEP] As the third millennium begins, Louisiana is again suffering the problem that has plagued it throughout its history. [SEP] Federal racketeering charges have been brought against Edwin Edwards —  Louisiana State Governor until his retirement in 1996 —  and the huge trial in Baton Rouge is keeping the state on the edge of its seat. [SEP] It seems that little has changed since the times of John Law.

column1: The Moors introduced new crops, including oranges and rice, to the region. [SEP] Their highly distinctive whitewashed houses and filigree chimneys are features of Portugal to this day, as are azulejos (handpainted, glazed ceramic tiles). [SEP] Many Moorish place names also survive, including that of Fátima, the pre-eminent Catholic site in Portugal. [SEP] Unlike their successors, the Moors were tolerant of the many different peoples who lived together in Portugal, including Berbers, Arabs, Christians, and Jews. [SEP] Even so, the Moors were regarded as an occupying power by the local Christian population. [SEP] The Christian Reconquest, which sought to
column3: the Muslims out, was under way in the north by the ninth century. [SEP] It was not until 1128, when Dom Afonso Henríques became the Count of Portucale, that the struggle to regain power met with any real success. [SEP] Henríques consolidated his position by defeating the Moors at the Battle of Ourique in 1139, and celebrated by naming himself the first king of Portugal.

column1: The topographical highlight of the Arrábida peninsula is undoubtedly the Serra da Arrábida (site of a nature reserve), a mountain chain around 35 km (22 miles) long which protects the coast from the strong north winds and accounts for the Mediterranean vegetation. [SEP] The tiny little beach spot, Portinho da Arrábida, is popular with Portuguese weekenders. [SEP] Setúbal, the district capital, is just a 20-minute
column3: from Lisbon by motorway, longer if you take the picturesque route via Sesimbra and Arrábida. [SEP] This is olive and citrus country, with cows grazing among the trees. [SEP] Setúbal is a conglomeration of market town, industrial center, resort, and Portugal’s third largest fishing port. [SEP] Setúbal’s greatest historical and artistic treasure, the Gothic Igreja de Jesus, was built around 1490 by the great French architect Boytac, who later built Lisbon’s glorious Jerónimos Monastery (see page 36). [SEP] A dramatic main portal leads into the church, which boasts two inspired elements of decoration: 17th-century azulejos on the walls, and stone pillars like twisted strands of clay, fragile-looking in spite of their obviously solid dimensions.

column1: Lamego has a wealth of handsome Baroque mansions, as well as a scenic 13th-century castle and a 16th-century Sé (cathedral) with a 12th-century tower. [SEP] The Museu de Lamego in the old bishop’s palace houses a fine collection of Flemish tapestries and religious statues, as well as paintings by Grão Vasco of the Viseu school (see page 56). [SEP] Pinhão, upriver from Régua (both the train trip and
column3: along the river in this stretch are stunning), is an enjoyable little town with deep connections to the port wine trade. [SEP] The tiny train station displays azulejos depicting the harvest, and many important quintas owned by the biggest port concerns, as well as independently owned vineyards, hug the hills near here. [SEP] Taylor, one of the major wine players, recently opened an excellent hotel in Pinhão, the appropriately named Vintage House. [SEP] From Pinhão to Pocinho, the train snakes along the Douro’s switchbacks with stunning views at every turn (2 hours roundtrip). [SEP] Another good route is north to Tua. [SEP] If you want to get closer to the wine production, you’ll need to have a car or arrange a tour with one of the quintas or local hotels. [SEP] Other towns ensconced in the

column1: The charming, sleepy town of Serpa rises neatly above the plains, 30 km (18 miles) east of Beja, on the route to Spain. [SEP] Beyond the formidable Porta da Beja, a monumental gate in the city wall, small streets wend among bright white houses. [SEP] Many of the buildings hide small cheese factories, which produce Serpa’s famous ewe’s milk cheese. [SEP] The town’s castle was partially destroyed by a Spanish attack in 1707, but still affords enjoyable views. [SEP] The walls continue past a privately owned 17th-century mansion and on to a slender aqueduct, which ends in an ancient well with a working chain-pulley system for drawing water. [SEP] A small ethnographic museum displays the wares of the agricultural and industrial workers of the area. [SEP] From Serpa a rewarding
column3: takes you south toward the eastern Algarve, through a hilly and sparsely populated landscape where shepherds tend their flocks. [SEP] Along the way is Mértola, an ancient white-washed town founded by the Phoenicians, built up by the Romans, and later seized by the Moors. [SEP] Perched on a ridge at the junction of the River Guadiana and the smaller Oeiras, the town is protected by Moorish walls and topped by a rather dilapidated castle with a profusion of storks’ nests. [SEP] Mértola bursts with history: Its church, the Igreja Matriz, betrays a previous incarnation as a mosque with a prayer niche (mihrab), while the town hall (now a museum) is constructed on Roman foundations. [SEP] The Guadiana River continues as far as the Algarve, forming part of the border with Spain. [SEP] The road tha

column1: s geographical context explains the strategic importance of Castro Marim, a fortress town occupied by the Moors for five centuries. [SEP] A little to the south, the sleepy but quietly dignified town of Vila Real de Santo António (the Royal Town of St. Anthony) is the last of the Algarve’s beach towns before Spain. [SEP] The town was built from scratch in just five months in 1774, aping the grid layout of Lisbon’s Baixa (lower city). [SEP] The town square, Praça do Marquês do Pombal, is the tour de force of Vila Real, with black-and-white pavement radiating from an obelisk in the center of the square like rays from the sun. [SEP] Vila Real de Santo António’s main appeal is the ferry to Ayamonte across the water in Spain. [SEP] The trip takes just 20 minutes — less time than it would take to
column3: to and over the new bridge — and the white town of Ayamonte is a fine sight as you approach it from the river. [SEP] Crossing into Spain, you will need to take your passport. [SEP] North from Sagres, along the west coast, is the one part of the Algarve that may well escape intensive development, simply because, although the beaches are pleasant and the coastline dramatic, the water is colder and the wind stronger. [SEP] For those interested in surfing or solitude, this coast may be ideal. [SEP] Aljezur’s ruined Moorish castle looks over the town, which makes a good base for neighboring beaches, such as the enormous rocky cove at Arrifana and the wider dune beach of Monte Clerigo, both of which also have their own small tourist complexes. column1: The road runs along the coastline and through the Bosque Estatal de Piñones, an area of beautiful sandy beaches and coconut palms that until recently was a pristine environment where sleepy cattle sat under the trees. [SEP] It is now a popular weekend picnic spot for city families, many of whom leave their litter behind when they depart. [SEP] This sort of carelessness spoils Piñones (and many other beauty spots on the eastern coastline within easy reach of San Juan); an assemblage of broken bottles, leftover food, litter, and worse is something you can’t fail to notice. [SEP] Head through Loíza, and on towards Río Grande. [SEP] Here Route 187 meets Route 3, one of the major arterial roads around Puerto Rico; it’s a very busy highway, so be aware and
column3: carefully. [SEP] Take a left and proceed to Route 191; then turn right and head up toward El Yunque (the Anvil), the most famous mountain in Puerto Rico. [SEP] Normally capped with clouds it catches from the passing sea breezes, and sometimes entirely lost in a blanket of gray storm-clouds, the 3,496-ft (1,088-m) peak stands at the center of the Caribbean National Forest, an area of virgin rain forest preserved since 1876, when the island was still a Spanish colony. [SEP] Originally a park of 12,300 acres (4,998 hectares), it now covers 28,000 acres (11,330 hectares) and is managed by the US Forestry Department. [SEP] The whole area is a place of staggering proportions: there are over 200 species of native trees. [SEP] One specimen is said to be over 2,500 years old; some trees are so wide

column1: at’s some 100 billion gallons (450 billion liters) of water. [SEP] The animals that live here are also amazing. [SEP] This is one of the last habitats of the threatened Puerto Rican parrot. [SEP] The infamous coquí (see page 47)is, of course, heard everywhere. [SEP] All in all, the park in an impressive sight, with slope after slope of vegetation laced with mountain streams and beautiful waterfalls and mountain peaks extend away into the distance. [SEP] Arriving via Route 191 you’ll come right to the El Portal Tropical Forest Center at the entrance to the park. [SEP] This facility presents important information about the history of the park, its plant and animal species, and its role in the local ecology. [SEP] You can then travel on higher into the park, toward the summit. [SEP] You can’t
column3: the whole 8 miles (13 km) between the visitors center and the end of the road, but there are several car parks and rest areas on the way, so there’s ample access. [SEP] Two popular stops are La Coca Falls, on the right after the 5-mile (8-km) point, and the Yokahú Observation Tower, at the 51⁄2-mile (9-km) point. [SEP] Here you can photograph the surrounding slopes. [SEP] The most spectacular cascade in the park, La Mina Falls, is just a 30-minute walk from the roadside, via Big Tree Trail. [SEP] Take a walk on any of the well-marked trails: the atmosphere is humid and the vegetation constantly damp (your best friends will be your insect repellent and your stout shoes), but the landscape is beautiful and fascinating.

column1: Traveling south from Fajardo you have the option of using Route 53 (a new toll road) or continuing on Route 3. [SEP] Both roads lead past to the town of Humacao, and on toward the south coast. [SEP] Just south of the Humacao is a left turn for Palmas del Mar, a growing resort area on the southeast coastline. [SEP] A residential resort community built around wonderful stretches of beach, the resort offers numerous activities, including horseback-riding, fishing, golf (two courses), and a casino. [SEP] East of the town of Yabucoa you’ll find the start of the Ruta Panoramica. [SEP] If you don’t have time to follow this entire trail, at least
column3: along Route 3 south of Yabucoa to the area around the Cendro la Pandura peak. [SEP] The road climbs via a series of switchback turns, and once at the top you’ll have a clear view of the town lying in the flat plain below. [SEP] The lifestyle of the people who live high on the hillside is fascinating. [SEP] Jíbaros (country farmers) carry machetes to the fields, accompanied by their faithful hounds. [SEP] Chickens scoot under cars as you approach. [SEP] Around every turn, you’ll marvel at how the houses can be built on such precipitous slopes. [SEP] The road then leads along the southern coastal plain through several small towns to Playa de [SEP] Ponce. Ponce

column1: orce base, are a series of fine bathing and surfing beaches. [SEP] The most famous is Crash Boat Beach, named after a shipwreck that happened just offshore. [SEP] The beach is always busy, but the most exciting stretch is the northern section, where the fishing boats rest. [SEP] Most hours of the morning there are ships coming ashore with their meager, but extremely fresh, catch. [SEP] The boats are brightly colored and carefully tended to ensure that they are always in peak condition — not one is splintered or sun-bleached. [SEP] Traveling back along the northern coast there is little to draw the eye. [SEP] Inland however, it’s a different story. [SEP] South of the busy town of Arecibo are a number of attractions that would make a fine day-trip from San Juan (none is more than a 90-minute
column3: from the capital). [SEP] Route 129 from Arecibo leads to one of the most important and mysterious scientific instruments in the world. [SEP] Arecibo Observatory has the largest single-dish radio telescope in the world; 1,000 ft (305 m) in diameter, it has been silently scanning the universe, making maps of distant solar systems, and listening for messages from other planets since 1960. [SEP] The Observatory is part of Cornell University’s National Astronomy and Ionosphere Center; it operates 24 hours a day. [SEP] The center likes to emphasize the serious scientific work it undertakes — such as detecting extremely weak radio pulses from the very corners of the known universe, which take 100 million years to reach the earth. column1: The whole cave park is a truly awesome sight, with holes 300 ft (91 m) deep and 200 ft (61 m) across, and caves thousands of feet deep, all surrounded by pristine forest. [SEP] Some say that the fountain of youth is here, in the clean water filtering through the limestone from the surface. [SEP] You don’t have to believe the legends, but taste the water anyway — it’s very sweet, and it can’t hurt to wish just a little. [SEP] From the caves it’s a short
column3: to Lares, the island’s center of coffee production. [SEP] The sweet brew made from Puerto Rican beans is considered one of the finest in the world, though production is small. [SEP] Coffee plants, usually interspersed with other crops such as bananas or plantains, can be seen growing on the high hillsides; it is a crop that enjoys good drainage and lots of humidity, which the large banana leaves help to conserve. [SEP] From Lares take Route 111 to reach the most important Amerindian site on Puerto Rico, the Parque Ceremonial Indígena Caguana (Caguana Indian Ceremonial Park).
